name: T√≠r na n√ìg
shortDescription: Land of eternal youth and beauty, a blessed otherworld realm beyond the western sea
fullDescription: T√≠r na n√ìg (Irish: Land of the Young) is one of the most beautiful realms of the Celtic Otherworld, a paradisal island beyond the western horizon where time stands still, no one ages, and sorrow is unknown. It is ruled by the fairy king Manannan mac Lir and inhabited by the Tuatha De Danann. Those mortals who journey there experience eternal youth and happiness, though returning to the mortal world causes all their accumulated years to catch up with them instantly.

geography.location: Beyond the western sea, accessible by magical voyage

events.name: Ois√≠n's Journey to T√≠r na n√ìg
events.description: The warrior-poet Ois√≠n is taken to T√≠r na n√ìg by Niamh of the Golden Hair. He lives there for what he believes is three years, but when he returns to Ireland, 300 years have passed

mythologyContexts.usage: Represents the ultimate paradise and the goal of spiritual questing. Serves as the destination for heroes, the dwelling of the immortal Tuatha De Danann, and a symbol of the timeless realm beyond mortal concerns

textReferences.context: The tale of Ois√≠n's journey to and return from the Land of Youth
Describes otherworld islands including lands of eternal youth

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Represents the soul's longing for immortality, the price of leaving the mortal world behind, and the impossibility of truly returning to innocence once it is lost. The time distortion symbolizes the otherworldly nature of mystical experience and enlightenment.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: T√≠r na n√ìg captures the Celtic fascination with otherworld realms and the bittersweet nature of immortality. It influenced later concepts of fairyland and paradise in Irish literature and became a powerful symbol of Ireland's mythic past and lost golden age.

linguistic.originalScript: Old Irish: T√≠r inna n-√ìc / Modern Irish: T√≠r na n√ìg

etymology.meaning: Land of the Young, Land of Youth
etymology.derivation: From Old Irish t√≠r (land, territory) + na (of the) + √≥g (young). Proto-Celtic *tƒ´ros (land) + *yuwHnÃ•kos (young). The eternal otherworld where none age

originPoint.name: Irish otherworld tradition
originPoint.description: Mythical realm located beyond the western sea, over the horizon from Ireland. Conceptually associated with Atlantic islands and the setting sun. Not a physical location but a spiritual otherworld realm

firstAttestation.source: Early Medieval Irish immrama and echtra
firstAttestation.description: Earliest references in voyage literature (Immram Brain, Serglige Con Culainn). The specific name 'T√≠r na n√ìg' becomes prominent in later medieval period and Ois√≠n ballads (18th-19th c.)

temporal.culturalPeriod: Iron Age through Medieval Irish tradition
